Hey guys! Ago_ with another update! Chapter 7 of "On the Fringes" is up, and begins on line 708.

https://pastebin.com/3NGXxFe1

>The sun had just passed the apex of its arc, and Vee and I were lucky to enter the woods at what was sure to be the hottest part of the day. The forest canopy blocked a substantial portion of the sunlight and immediately I could feel the air temperature drop beneath the trees. My bare feet were already aching and of everything I had lost in the last twenty-four hours, I really wished I still had my boots. That Vee needed no sleeve or padding or some other thing between her tail and the ground was momentarily interesting, but then again her scales probably acted as some sort of armor. Whereas she could probably barely feel the pine cones and needles and twigs that crunched beneath her, I was gingerly stepping over this and that while trying my best not to fall behind or slow her down. Whoever it was Vee thought we were going to run into, I sure hoped they had a spare pair of shoes I could trade for. That was if they didn't kill us first.

>"Stop," Vee said. I froze mid-stride, carefully putting my foot down avoid making any sound. She sank low to the ground, using her hands to support herself, and flicked her tongue several times over a particular spot. "Blood."

As always, I appreciate and read all feedback, good or bad. Like every writer I'm sure, I'd love to hear what you think.

Miles DF falls into that particular situation of being one of the few furry artists who were the best digital artist when the medium was just beginning. Miles-DF may be making bank but over the greater furry space there seems to be not a ton of intrest.

Anonymous Sun 12 Jul 2020 16:10:55 No.31448440 Report
Quoted By: >>31448998
>>31448289
Writing is basically just practice and copying what you like. People like to bandy about all kinds of silver bullet rules that will magically make your writing better, but it's honestly a lot more soft than that. It often comes down to what sounds right, and that can depend on a lot of factors. For instance, one often cited beginners' error is a viewpoint character finding an excuse to describe themselves. That seems like the sort of information we ought to have for our imaginations, but in reality it jars our suspension of disbelief because it's so obviously done for the benefit of the reader, while people in general don't think a lot about what they're wearing and how they've done up their hair.
Anonymous

Feeling guilty, they start Hawthorne on a recovery program, trying to get him above an IQ were the recruiting officer must have cheated on the form to get him in.
But then they deploy.

Anonymous Sun 12 Jul 2020 16:42:06 No.31448998 Report
Quoted By:
>>31448440
this
also, don't force things. Let your characters flow and if you find them flowing in a direction you don't like, change something up stream. Maybe introduce a new character that directs them in the direction you've been wanting to go in.

For instance, Andy Weir wrote the Martian backwards, throwing problems at Watney and introducing the parts that he needed to solve these problems retroactively earlier in the story.
Finally: write from your perspective for your first few stories, then switch to third. I find the former easier to write, while the later automatically makes it harder to introduce mary sue-esque problem characters.

And please don't force humor if you're not a comedian. No one utters one liners in a constant stream, it makes your characters look silly. Think about what they would say, then think about how others would react to the tone and conveyed information. Your story will be more difficult to write, but complex characters interacting naturally and consistently make a story so much more rewarding to read.
"a furry walked in
she was hot
so was I
she had left open the door
we dropped to the floor
no one walked the dinosaur
[drop extensive explanation on titties bouncing and how hard a dick is plus at least 30 female orgasms]"
that's just boring writing.
Think about your characters and what you think they would do, then write that. Let them react to the world you set, assign them base traits and a back story.

Anonymous Sun 12 Jul 2020 17:18:57 No.31449428 Report
Quoted By: >>31450057
>>31448289
>tips for writing
Read more of what you want to write. If you like fantasy, read that. Scifi? Go wild. Read different authors. Reading is proven to improve vocabulary, writing, AND speaking ability.

Don't be afraid of tropes. Tropes are used a lot because they work and people like them. It is a small subsection of the populace who feels the need to point out everything they read and immediately connect it to a tvtropes page. Just dont go overboard, and when possible, cleverly subvert them in ways that enhance your characters and their stories.

My biggest one is WRITE FOR YOURSELF. Do NOT -- UNDER ANY CIRCUMSTANCES -- CONFLATE YOUR WRITING SKILL WITH THE NUMBER OF (You)s OR LIKES OR REBLOGS OR WHATEVER. That is a very dangerous road to go down and saps motivation. I know from experience.

On the note of writing skill, should you use some free wore counters on the internet, disregard the "writing level" indicator. It tells you if the vocabulary used would be understood by middle schoolers, high schoolers, etc. IT DOES NOT tell you what level your writing ability is.

Some people put out thousands of words a day, others put out a few hundred but constantly update. Some dont update for weeks or months. Do not link writing skill to speed or volume. Go at your own pace.
Anonymous

Anonymous Sun 12 Jul 2020 17:46:58 No.31449753 Report
Quoted By:
>>31448289
To a large degree, stay away from here while working and don't force the story on the characters.
Both will set you up for failure.
Your characters aren't you, so get used to the feeling of being someone's voice.
And getting too deep in the shitposting here can lead to writing by committee. While some of the more popular characters here have 10x the amount of discussion versus story, a team of Anons isn't writing it for you. They can tell you afterwards what they thought.

Build around a small core. Whether that's an idea or a fragment of conversation, expand on it. Outline if needed. Be prepared to throw all but one sentence away.

Anonymous Sun 12 Jul 2020 18:10:30 No.31450057 Report
Quoted By: >>31450726
>>31448289
>writing tips

>>31449428
>tropes
I do want to say being aware of tropes is a blessing and a curse. On the one hand it can make you feel like every thing has already been done. On the other hand looking at examples like the monomyth work of Campbell or Jungian archetypes shows that there are endless ways to retell the same story and have people take away new things from it.

Tropes tend to be a disaster when you set out to make them, especially the more specific or niche they are. Because that's when you start getting lazy in your writing to shoehorn a character or setting or event into the trope. Like a lot of bad "anti-hero protagonist" characters are just normal heroes who dress like a villain and say mean or edgy things. A good anti-hero is someone struggling with their own moral failings or seeking redemption for past acts, the internal struggle expresses itself with the character solving problems in a way that a heroic protagonist might question or outright object to.

>WRITE FOR YOURSELF
I disagree with this a little. If you are telling a story to yourself, why write it down and share it with others? A story that you want to share is by definition something you are making for other people. Yeah people write things down just to get them out of their own head, a la a journal. But if were talking about writing a story intended to be shared, it's different.

This doesn't mean you should bend over to popular demand (or the demand of a loud minority either) but it does mean you have to respect feedback. It's easy to get discouraged by the negative feedback, but the opposite trap also exists. It's easy to convince yourself all feedback is useless or dishonestly motivated, so you never reflect and improve. Look around on DA and you'll see artists who have had the same terrible "style" for ten years because of that attitude.
Anonymous

Anonymous Sun 12 Jul 2020 21:14:13 No.31452778 Report
Quoted By: >>31453347
>>31451865
>peak oil
Probably not the best comparison, since peak oil (and most other resource type deals) as a crisis scenario essentially only exists in the minds of people who didn't understand how reserves get reported, and to a secondary extent people who didn't quite get the economic theory behind it. Advances in both extraction technology and in renewable alternatives mean that while we do need to act on things, we've actually got an extremely comfortable margin to get off oil. The price spikes have always been down to conflicts and cartel-enforced artificial scarcity being played as a political lever.
Fucking ourselves up is most likely to happen because of something like us getting advanced enough that a tiny, backwards nation is able to beggar itself powerful enough nukes that it's too demented to not use, but that also leaves us in too much of a mess to build spaceships.
There's climate stuff I suppose, but people don't generally appreciate the time scales that actually occurs over. It'd be extremely uncomfortable, but even the scenarios that assumed we would do less than we're currently doing to remedy things would be unlikely to pose any sort of existential threat to us, it would just risk ethically unacceptable disruption to other species.
When you get down to it though, for the sake of alt-history plot device it's all fair game. It seems like it'd be difficult to tie together the apparent affection held towards humans if they were actually directly responsible for something so catastrophically destructive as to threaten our own extinction.

In any case I'm more interested to know why they seem to dote so heavily.

Anon serves as enlisted on a submarine full of anthros and they keep agressively flirting with him while he flirts back, but the officers always interrupt whenever it gets more serious. Until one day in the weight room.

Anon is a hitchhiker that gets a lift by an anthro trucker. They both want to go in the same direction, but when the truck breaks down, they're forced to make sleeping in her cabin work for them as nothing seems to pass on the road they are on.

Anon invests in the wrong thing and suddenly finds himself a roommate of an anthro after no one else wanted him.

Furry aliens kidnap anon and unlike little green men, anon is the one doing the anal probing
